description: Close analysis of the 5/7/1994 Phish 'Split Open and Melt' jam.
Jam is performed by Phish.
Uses Super Mario Galaxy as a case study in applying film-analytic traditions to game music.
Examines how design of World of Warcraft structures access to its music.
Interprets contradictions in the music and narrative of Katamari Damacy.
Treats Guitar Hero as a paradigmatic music game with notated performance.
Discusses BIT.TRIP BEAT as a game that links obstacles and music.
Analyzes BIT.TRIP RUNNER and its musically organized geography.
Uses Dyad as an example of an active score whose music is realized through play.
Asks whether L.A. Noire can be read as a music game via its investigative cues.
Reads The Rocky Horror Picture Show through its vocal timbre and instrumentation.
Compares Glee's 'The Rocky Horror Glee Show' episode with the original film.
Introduces 'structural fog' to describe high-intensity, densely layered grooves.
Connects listeners' experience of structural fog to jouissance.
Builds on groove theory to explain long-form improvisation.
Uses Keil's participatory discrepancies as a foundation for groove analysis.
Provides a calculus-based model for finite metric dissonances.
Models grouping dissonance and its summation over time.
Coins and taxonomizes barriers to listening in a large-scale online game.
Defines synchronic barriers tied to player situation in the current version of the game.
Defines diachronic barriers that emerge across the game's lifespan.
Argues that in some games the world functions as a musical score.
Situates titles like Guitar Hero and Dyad within the category of music games.
Questions the assumption of ludic primacy in game-music discourse.
Challenges views of music as merely supplementary to gameplay.
Uses transformational networks to analyze key relations in Super Mario Galaxy.
Employs neo-Riemannian operations to trace tonal paths between galaxies.
Adapts Schenkerian methods to game music, including boss themes.
Uses Tonnetz diagrams to visualize transformational spaces.
Places the study within broader analytical traditions in ludomusicology.
Shows how Katamari's cheerful music coexists with darker narrative implications.
Uses vocal and timbral analysis to read gender and sexuality in Rocky Horror and Glee.
Argues that musical details ultimately reinforce masculine agency.
Shows tensions between the film's apparent sexual liberation and its musical rhetoric.
Relates barriers-to-listening framework to ongoing work in ludomusicology.
Connects the game-world-as-score idea to the broader field of ludomusicology.
Structural fog is proposed as a musical condition that can elicit jouissance.
Structural fog is a specific state within ongoing groove.
Grouping dissonance is described as a subtype of metric dissonance.
Synchronic barriers are one axis of the barriers-to-listening taxonomy.
Diachronic barriers form the other axis of the taxonomy.
Timbral readings support claims about how agency is gendered.
Structural fog is mapped across loops of the Split Open and Melt jam.
Metric dissonance is the core analytical focus of the article.
Barriers to listening determine who can hear which music in World of Warcraft.
BIT.TRIP RUNNER's level geography functions as a kind of scrollable score.
Dyad's cylindrical track and events are treated as a kind of musical notation.
The article asks whether L.A. Noire's investigation cues justify reading it as a music game.
Guitar Hero is treated as a central example of a music game.
BIT.TRIP BEAT is categorized as a music game.
BIT.TRIP RUNNER is categorized as a music game.
Dyad is categorized as a music game.
Transformational networks model tonal relations among Super Mario Galaxy levels.
Neo-Riemannian operations track moves between key centers in the game.
Schenkerian reductions interpret boss themes and level music.
Cheerful surface music contrasts with darker implications in Katamari Damacy.
Campy rock musical style coexists with conservative resolutions of gender roles.
Vocal timbres in the film are read as gendered signifiers.
Glee's cover performances are compared through their timbral profiles.
